reviewText:
This VN has the typical setup of the main character returning to town for a few days after being away for a few years. You spend your time back visiting two girls each with very different personalities. One is your typical loud & fun loving girl (Amu) and the other is the shy & reserved type (Noelle). There are a decent amount of choices to be made. Start to finish clocked in at 61 minutes for me, I could see it being around 90 minutes or so if you're a slower reader. There are also 21 endings to see!

That being said the game suffers from Subpar artwork (downright horrid in some places), Terrible Music & an incredible amount of filler that drags some scenes on for far too long. I was practically falling asleep at my PC reading this. With faults like that, why would I recommend this VN? The answer is simple. The final chapter. The game takes quite a turn fast and suddenly these faults take a backseat to the chain of events that happen. I don't want to say what exactly because that would spoil the fun but trust me it's absolutely mental and made this worthwhile. I went from falling asleep to the edge of my seat in 30 seconds flat. If you're an anime watcher, I'll just say that this is the School Days" of VNs. Glad I bought it.

Edit: 5/21 endings now. All of which are very well done. Most things struggle to have a satisfying ending
date: but at this rate this VN is going to have 21 of them. It's just a shame that the first 70% of it is so bland."
helpfulPercent: 46 of 50 people (92%) found this review helpful 5 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Dark, Dark, Dark...Dark.
At times this made my heart sick and I wanted to scream.
There are 21 endings and I have completed them all (thanks to this walk through: http://lemmasoft.renai.us/forums/viewtopic.php?f=55&t=28135) and they are not all rainbows and unicorns.

That is not what I really expected with blood spatter on the title page but some of these endings took my breath away.
There are some happy endings, but overall I have a not-so-happy feeling when all the endings are added together.

The amazing thing is that each ending is believable. Despite the twists and turns, you can say 'I see how I arrived here' in the end. It was surprising to see how simple choices had a major impact on the story and you arrived at different endings.

At the completion of some endings, there is a little behind the scenes or after story. It explains some of what happened before or shows what happens after the ending. Again the detail that went into all this is impressive. It all fits so well together and really is an excellent story / game / VN.


The only down side I found was some of the dialog was long - that is just me though, a little impatient. There is an option to skip thorough that dialog which is helpful particularly if you have already gone through that chain once before.

So if you are wondering if you should get this, the answer is: Yes. ... and prepare to have a not so happy but incredible adventure.
voteText: 30 of 30 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The Way We ALL GO is a visual novel about a shy, generally incompetent boy returning to his small-town home for a few days after two years in the city.  He meets up with old friends and neighbors and hopefully makes up for old mistakes that he had been running away from.

The Way We ALL GO is hard not to compare to Higurashi, at least initially.  It has a similar setting with some similar elements and the backgrounds in particular would fit perfectly in the original version of Higurashi.  Even the name and blood-splatter theme of the UI evoke Higurashi somewhat.

However, the game itself is decidedly not a Higurashi ripoff.  For starters, it has choices.  Lots of them.  There are 21 endings in total and the routes leading to them vary significantly, especially for that 21st ending.  Also, the story remains rooted in something resembling reality.

The game does get violent sometimes, as the blood-splatters imply, but I wouldn't say that's the point of the game.  I've certainly played some VNs whose stories seemed more like an excuse for torture porn than an actual narrative, but thankfully this is not one of them.  It is more than possible to achieve an actual happy ending.

The game can take a while to get going.  Sometimes it feels like it takes about twice as long as it needs to in order to get something across in a conversation.  However, once you get through the early game and can start working through the endings, it really picks up.  I was pretty down on it early on, to be honest, but in the end I genuinely think this is one of the better western VNs I've played.

P.S. Paya is the best.
voteText: 20 of 21 people (95%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've bought several games on Steam and for whatever reason this is the first one that I wanted to sit down and review.

Whether you call this a game is up for debate, since it's arguably a visual novel. To really enjoy it, you need to like strong narratives and character driven plots.

But this little slice of life, quirky game drew me in, with characters that had depth and moments where I, the player, had to make a choice completely drawing me in. It also helps that there are 21 ENDINGS, and the first one I got came so completely out of the blue (#6) that I just had to find the rest, since the story is set up so that you know there's more to discover than you can on a single playthrough.

Graphically, it's anime-ish with some still pictures, changing expressions and watercolour backgrounds. The hairstyles are very anime, but realism doesn't seem to be the goal here. Instead, it's a unique, immersive little experience. It'd be nice to see this game get more reviews and support, since production values are smooth and professional.

If I still feel the same after playing through all 21 endings, I might amend my statement. However, the game also has some handy little features (like letting you skip dialogue) to make repeat playthroughs more bearable.

The only thing I would say I dislike is that if this turns into a love sim type experience, it feels as though the developers expects the player to favour one girl over another, and in my case I prefer the other character. This can lead to making some choices in the game out of belligerence and getting annoyed if the game's responding text reprimands you. This was also present in the demo!

However, if you like visual novels I'd say give this a go.

reviewText:
I bought this VN since it reminded me of Higurashi. And I’m really shocked by the fact that there’s a TON of things to do: your choices, all of them, really matter on changing your destiny. Art style, BG, BGM were nicely done. Story and characters were also amazing.

This VN is worth every cent! Although, I do not recommend this game if you feel triggered about violence, blood, depression, paranoia… If you don’t mind, go for it without fear: the game is so good and worth to pay the full price.

I love how the art style is cute, but the story itself is a different thing. And 21 different endings are quite an accomplishment.

10/10.

reviewText:
To be honest, I didn't expect this novel to be that good. I saw quirky drawings and as soon as I opened the game I heared kind of annoying soundtrack. And it could've been the end to my experience with it, but I gave it a shot anyway. And - ohboi! - I don't regret it.
The game follows a story of a shy and insecure guy Attchan who comes back to his homevillage to visit his grandparents for just three days. While there, the character decides to visit (or, as one of the option states, not to) his childhood friends: Amu and Noele. It sounds kinda basic, but if I go without any spoilers, I'd say that there is a very interesting kind of chracters hiding behind such a basic concept. Really, just read it for yourselfs, through all the filler episodes and a boring start. This novel has an advantage of being short, just about 3 and a half hours (if you read in carefully) to get one ending. There are not that many differences between endings concerning the actual story, just a few more scenes or episodes, but it is satisfying.
What really helps the game is it's soundtrack. It does sound cheap, but it fits perfectly with the spirit of the whole story, so that's why it works.
However, the main con of the game is it's sprites and drawings. When characters are descent (just slightly above average), the backgrounds are terrible and seem just like photos rendered with a filter. But, as bad as it may sound, it doesn't really matter, as that simply what it is: a background. It doesn't spoil the story, and that's what matters.

Overall, I'll admit that this is, by far, one of the best visual novels I've ever read, and I've read A LOT of them. This one's short, full of emotions, good memorable characters and atmospheric soundtrack. If only the drawings could've been better, we would've had ourselves a perfect visual novel of it's kind.
8.5-9/10

P.S.  Noelle is the best, even with that little box cutter of hers and blood on her hands.

reviewText:
So, after a while, I finally forced myself to write this review.
Reason why I was forcing myself was because this was my very first visual novel (VN), so I was not sure whether to write one or not, but hey, why not express my opinion as well ;)

As I said already, this is my first VN so I did not really know what I was going into.
Beggining of  the story is rather weak, you are on a train, playing as main protagonist nicknamed Atcchan, who is on the way to a small village to visit his grand parents. You then meet your childhood friends, Amu and Noelle and couple of other characters. My very first impressions were mixed. There are multiple endings and routes to them. On my first playthrough, which took roughly 5 hours, I got ending that was way too sweet and happy and felt a bit too perfect, but that is only me. On my second playthrough though, oh boy, was I not prepared for this.

There is not much to a story, there are no robots, aliens, catgirls ;_;, really, just you and your friends talking and dialog in this game is very well-made, but sometimes it feels like it tries to be way too artistic. It is very character-driven story, so characters better be interesting, right? Are characters here interesting? Yeah, I like all of them, especially Amu. However, the weakest one was deffinitely Noelle. She is quiet, shy and lacks any self-confidence. You can make interesting characters with this concept, but here, she felt kinda one-dimensional. Later on in almost every route revolving around her 80% (number pulled out of nowhere) of every dialog with her turned into her pitying herself, it goes without saying that it got repetetive.

Speaking of ,,later on

reviewText: Very dark and sad at times. Deals with some mature themes like suicide, murder, animal abuse, depression and assault. Can be graphic (bloody) at points, but I would recommend, as it is a good read and there are 21 different endings. However, many of them can be difficult to trigger, and a lot of the dialogue leading to the endings are very much the same. There are a few endings that are not very different from each other either.\n\nThe writing isn't bad (but not great, it does have it's great moments though), the artwork is decent at best and the lack of voice acting/additional artwork is disappointing. reviewText: i actually played this a while ago when it was still the free, far shorter version, and thought it was pretty alright back then, but it's really improved a fair amount. the higurashi feel is something a little hard to escape from, and the game plays a lot older than it is, but for anyone who's taking a chance on random vn's made by individual people you could do a lot worse on the steam selections. the art and engine seem a little dated, maybe 2008-ish, but theyre perfectly fine, and its the writing where a lot of the best parts are. characters and situations are established quickly and naturally, and the narrative structure is very effective to meet the story's ends\n\nmaybe not the best for someone who's new to the whole visual novel thing, but for anyone who's been around for a while, definitely something you shouldnt miss. well worth the price

reviewText:
The way we ALL GO is well-written VN with a huge variety of endings.

The choices you make throughout this game will decide which one of the 21 different possible endings you can get. I would recommend using a walkthrough to reach 100% completion of this game, as it takes a veeery long time to get to an ending if you dont skip dialogue. However if you are attempting to get all the endings, there is an extremely useful skip button, which lets you skip text that you have already seen without doing anything

All in all, this is my favourite VN, which can provide heart-warming moments, as well as tear-jerking ones.

9.5/10

EDIT: The game now has achievements!

New rating:
10/10

reviewText: I was initially having some trouble getting into this visual novel but as I went for more and more of the 21 endings, the story really felt a lot deeper than it initially appeared. It seemed inspired by Higurashi at times, and there are some very dark scenes, but on the whole, the game stands on it's own and doesn't try to be scary or horrifying most of the time. The art is serviceable but not that great, and the main character can be a bit on the annoying side. Another issue I had is that while there are a lot of good scenes, many of them go on for FAR longer than necessary, to the point where it feels like the characters will never stop talking and repeating themselves. But despite the complaints, I really felt compelled to see everything and finish the game 100%. I reccomend it if you're looking for something a little quirky to add to your VN collection.

reviewText: Didn't expect much from this VN, but it's surprisingly good. I like heavily branching plot (though I had to look up for walkthrough to find all the endings). It has enough dark and gory twists, often unexpected - the first ending I got was №2, really didn't see that coming. Another ending that caught me off-guard was №13. And ending 18 is hilarious, in a way. In contrast with all the horror the events can turn to, good endings feel really heartwarming, if sometimes bittersweet. Overall, the story is good and characters are memorable.\nThe game really reminds a bit of Higurashi (to which it has some shout-outs). Interestingly, it also has similar flaws: some scenes feel too long and a bit boring, and the art is mediocre (still better than original Higurashi art, anyway).\nSome things I subjectively disliked: Atcchan is such a doormat, instead of feeling sorry for him in bad endings, I felt some kind of amusement. And Noelle - she is a type of character I usually like and can relate to, thought she was going to be my favorite... then I kept getting bad endings with her and was like What the hell is wrong with this girl?". Even after I cleared her best route
date: which explains why she behaves as she is and really made me sorry for her
recommended: I just... still don't like her. My favorite character would be Paya.\nI definitely would recommend this game to anyone who likes visual novels."

It is pointlessly long, so far I have gotten through 4-5 endings and all I can think of is how annoying and wimpy the main character is. reviewText:
Dialogue and narration are pointlessly meandering. Lots of flashbacks to scenes that just happened, and the main character ruminating on them, revealing nothing that wasn't implicit in the scenes already.

Characters don't come off as authentic. They feel like stock characters written through the view of the author's nostalgia goggles.

Art is ..... bad.

The few endings I read through didn't seem to do much beyond genre expectations.

There's a slim chance that the other endings were fantastic and I just missed out, but the prospect of slogging through that text again wasn't tempting.

If you want a long-winded, predictable yandere game, it's for you. But anything more and you'll be disappointed.

reviewText:
This game has beautiful music, amazing artwork, and an absolutely breath-taking story. The characters are so memorable, once I had a nightmare that Noelle killed me with that box cutter. Seroiusly.

For all it does right, some things should've been diferent. For one, the background gets kinda lazy when it becomes night time. It just looks like the brightness was decreased. Also, some endings are too similar to eachother.

But one thing the game does amazingly is the choices. Most of the time, I found myself going crazy tyring to pick one choice over another. The choices you make in the game really make you feel like you are Attchan; trying to make the best of your short three days back home.

The endings are amazing. Due to Noelle being a total yandere, most of them are kinda... deathy. Some were happy endings, some were wierd, and in some of them... Attchan gets killed.But, I loved all of them. It was a fun journey getting all the endings, and I couldn't possibly pick my favorite one.

In short, this game is amazing. Nothing else could be said.

date: but exploring the many branching paths and alternate endings reveals a surprising level of depth and a very satisfying amount of total content (~13 hours for all routes). This story lets you ride the emotional highs and lows
recommended: from heartwarming happy ends  to... well

reviewText:
This game started out, just okay. Seemed pretty cliched. I wondered why a game like this had the kind of dark art around it, when it was a seemingly nice game. HOWEVER, after reaching some of the endings, I gotta say I wasn't expecting how some of them turned out. Now I'm actually going through trying to unlock the different endings. It picks up pretty quick, the story,
The amount of choices and endings is great and gives the game a great replay value.
As others say the art and music ins't top of the line, and it's not, but it can be overlooked pretty easily.
with all the endings you'll definitly find one you like, or really don't like! I've only gotten like 4 of them so far, so I can't say if they'll get better or worse but the endings I've gotten so far have made the game totally worth it.
I would recommend this game to friends

reviewText:
I've lost count of how many times  Noelle has killed me ...

But I still enjoyed the other parts of this game that I've seen. I've so far completed ten of the 21 routes, in 15 hours of gameplay. From this amount of play time, I believe that the price of the game is reasonable for its length. The characters in the game were great because you get a wide range of personalities, some of which are more likeable than others.

However, I do believe that this game could've done even better if it had more of a dating simulator aspect to it. There are some romantic moments in some of the routes, but not nearly as much as most of the other dating sim games I've played on Steam. I think this game could've easily been pulled off as a dating sim game, since it had all of the other qualities of dating sims: multiple women, story choices, distinct routes, etc.

Despite this slight disappointment, I still recommend this game to those who enjoy anime visual novels with choices that decide the route you take in the game.

reviewText:
With nice selections of OST and interesting writing, I could enjoy a lot.
I've been away from books for a long time, and this amazing VN made me allowed to have some fun with reading and let me relaxed while reading.
While it needs a little bit of understanding of Japanese culture to fully understand what author wanted to say, well it's still good without it.
It's a indie game, but it worth playing more than some of commercial VN that has non-depth writing.

Anyway, most of readers would not regret buying this. Definitely I recommend this VN.

reviewText: This game is really good. There are multiple endings. You are definitely getting your money's worth given how long the game actually is. For positives, the special effects are actually pretty good. Each character has their own quirks and feel fleshed out. The story itself makes sense. Given the relatively cheap price, I would definitely recommend this game even over Ebi-hime's other works.

reviewText:
I have to admit, at first, when I started playing. I was a little bored and not interested. It had lots of talk and lots of unnecessary details.  As others said, the main character isn't very good or relatable. But honestly? It fits the story and might be creative (not GREAT, but it fits the story and characters; this matters for VNs after all) choice. Once I neared one of the good endings, I started enjoying it. It was almost a fun romance VN. Definitely interesting again.
I would have said 6/10 perhaps with that ending. Then I started hunting all ends.  Unanswered questions started to be answered and I saw the truth of the VN, the gritty story.

Now I like it alot. 8/10 perhaps. It's definitely fun and I liked it alot. It's not a pure innocent story (not even in the good ending I got on my own). It's definitely SIMILAR to Higurashi but not the same thing. I think it's worth trying out. Definitely do a bad ending for good measure.  And it DOES give you emotions and feelings. it's not an empty VN and wil make you feel true emotions.

It's good if not a bit slow.

Only real complaint:
>MC is a bit weak
>Slow scenes
>CG scenes for ONE girl are bad, but amazing for another girl
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
First things first, it should be emphasized that this is a friendship focused visual novel rather than a romance focused one. While some of the good endings have romance, most of them do not, and Noelle's psychotic obsession over Atcchan is more platonic than outright romantic.

While the plot is ultimately mundane, the inter-character drama is captivating and fairly realistic. All of the characters are interesting in their own right, even the minor ones. Even Eri, who appears the least of the three heroines, is a well developed character. However, Noelle is arguably the most developed. Even in the Amu focused and Eri focused routes, Noelle is an important player while Amu is mostly uninvolved in the Noelle route. While there is some outright violence, it's mostly restricted to the bad endings. Be wary of some dark topics nonetheless.

I recommend that you play the endings in order, or if nothing else, play the Comiket route last after doing every other ending. While the game peaks in drama at the Noelle focused route (endings 11-12), the Comiket route does an good job of wrapping up the conflicts and plot points referenced in all of the other routes at once. Sometimes it resolves a conflict off-screen, and sometimes it only off-handedly mentions it , but despite seeming like a gag route and not having a lot of drama, the Comiket route is a satisfying end to the game.

Cons:
Some of the writing is honestly a bit stilted and could use some work. Furthermore, the pacing wasn't stellar. The events in the game span about three days, and much of the first day is fluff. In addition, the sprites aren't the best. Inconsistent CGs are also a minor minus. As I tend to evaluate visual novels on the novel part rather than the visual, I didn't really mind the art style issues though.

7/10 which vaguely means a solid VN; stick on your backlog to play sometime if you're interested.
